abstracts.cdata!:
The project ratings are as follows:
            Project outcome is satisfactory; sustainability is likely;
            institutional development impact is substantial; Bank
            performance is satisfactory; and Borrower performance is
            satisfactory. Among the lessons learned were the following:
            1) Complex projects with multiple objectives and the large
            number of components pose a risk of project delays. 2) The
            project objectives and components should have a direct and
            strong relationship to ensure success in achieving project
            objectives. 3) The readiness for implementation, timing of
            reforms, and level of commitment of the borrower to
            implement the proposed reforms have to be ensured during
            project appraisal. 4) The cost estimates of the borrower
            should be rechecked carefully against international
            (comparable countries) and historical prices to avoid high
            levels of savings. 5) Monitoring indicators should be based
            on well-defined data that are routinely collected by the borrower.

5864778.trustfund:
TF021251-PHRD-JAPANESE CTF (USD ACCOUNT),TF023093-PHRD-RAILWAYS VII PROJECT,TF029527-PHRD-FORESTRY RESOUR.DEV.&
            CONSER.(ORIG. REC-EXE. NOW BANK EXE),TF031676-CHINA - SEVEN RAILWAY PROJECT

repnme.cdata!:
China - Seventh Railway Project -
            environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Seventh Railway Project includes the
            expansion of corridor capacity for railway reform. This
            report covers the environmental assessment of the Wuchang -
            Guangzhou railway capacity extension, expected to have an
            increased passenger and freight turnover along the
            Guangdong, Hubei, and Hunan provinces. The main
            environmental impacts during construction relate to harmful
            effects on the soil, namely vegetation and farmland, water
            and air pollution, and noise related interference, such as
            blast vibrations. Furthermore, following construction, noise
            disturbance is expected to affect the nearby population,
            which includes affected schools and hospitals. The impact on
            population reallocation will be treated separately in the
            resettlement action plan. Mitigation measures to curb the
            environmental impacts will be controlled by the
            environmental protection personnel, according to local
            protection regulations, and include: clearing domestic
            refuse and waste water, as well as standard maintenance
            discharge control on air pollutants; alleviating noise
            through vibration-reducing mounts and boundary noise limits;
            regulation on electromagnetic radiation; and, schools and
            hospitals along the line will require enclosed corridor
            windows for noise reduction, as well as installation of air
            conditioning and ventilation facilities.

China - Seventh Railway Project -
            environmental assessment

0.cdata!:
Wuchang - Guangzhou Railway Capacity
            Expansion Project

repnme.cdata!:
China - Seventh Railway Project -
            resettlement action plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The resettlement action plan (RAP) for
            the Wuchang - Guangzhou railway corridor capacity expansion
            is based on investigations of property damage, determination
            of project impacts, analysis of governing policies and
            regulations, and consultation with the affected population.
            The RAP provides mitigation measures for the affected
            population, fostering the chance of raising/restoring their
            standard of living. These measures stipulate that: 1) the
            agricultural population resettlement should be dependent on
            land compensation transfers, thus minimizing resettlement
            risks, allowing for irrigation improvements, soil
            amelioration, and a sustainable animal and crop production.
            Further, as a potential to alter the rural setup,
            consideration should be given to industrial development; 2)
            appropriate training should be provided as needed whenever
            job transfers are considered; 3) urban housing compensation
            standards are to be determined according to the
            reconstruction price; 4) enterprises' resettlement
            compensation is also to be determined according to the
            reconstruction price, with no depreciation value. The RAP
            encourages community participation and suggests the
            provision of grievance appeal mechanisms during displacement.

display_title.display_title:
China - Seventh Railway Project -
            resettlement action plan (Vol. 2) : Appendix

18225708.admreg: East Asia and Pacific,East Asia and Pacific
18225708.theme: Infrastructure services for private sector development,Administrative and civil service reform
18225708.trustfund:
TF023093-PHRD-RAILWAYS VII PROJECT,TF031676-CHINA - SEVEN RAILWAY PROJECT,TF029527-PHRD-FORESTRY RESOUR.DEV.&
            CONSER.(ORIG. REC-EXE. NOW BANK EXE),TF021251-PHRD-JAPANESE CTF (USD ACCOUNT)
18225708.majtheme: Financial and private sector development,Public sector governance

abstracts.cdata!:
The Seventh Railway Project will support
            the Ministry of Railways' (MOR) initial efforts to
            implement its 30-point action statement of railway reform.
            The project's main objectives are to assist MOR: 1)
            redefine the relationship between the railway and the
            Government; 2) reshape the railway's organization and
            strengthen its internal management; 3) expand the
            railway's transport capacity, raise its investment
            efficiency, and enhance its finances; and 4) modernize the
            railway's technologies and bolster the efficiency and
            quality of its transport operations and service. To achieve
            these objectives, MOR formulated a series of components on
            policy reform and institutional development (PID),
            investments, and studies. PID components include: 1) railway
            enterprise reform; 2) railway tariff reform; and 3) labor
            productivity enhancement. Investments include: 1) expanding
            corridor capacity; 2) modernizing information systems; 3)
            upgrading telecommunications systems; 4) commercializing
            container transport; 5) enhancing environmental protection;
            and 6) expanding system capacity. The studies include
            components that will provide MOR with the technical
            assistance and software needed to prepare future railway
            projects or to develop and apply new railway technologies
            and management techniques.
